topics.title: Beauty enhances functionality and builds trust
topics.summary: Katie argues beauty and functionality aren’t opposites: beauty improves usability, approachability, and trust by signaling care and attention to detail.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Katie’s roles at Stripe, Lyft, and Airbnb and previews topics like scaling design teams, operationalizing quality, and design’s impact on growth.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Sidebar (peer groups/personal board of directors) and Jira Product Discovery (prioritization and roadmapping tool).

topics.title: Airbnb design team intervention and trust lesson
topics.summary: Katie recounts an early Airbnb “intervention” where designers delivered blunt feedback; she realized she hadn’t earned trust and shifted from “coming in swinging” to listening and bringing the team along, improving engagement scores.

topics.title: Org design: sitting together and dual identity
topics.summary: They discuss co-locating cross-functional teams while also building a strong design community—wearing both the “Design” and product-area “T-shirt.”

topics.title: Making the ROI case for design quality
topics.summary: Katie breaks down levels of quality, explains why teams over-prioritize measurable features, and argues “quality is growth,” citing Stripe examples like onboarding improvements and checkout changes driving a 10.5% revenue lift.

topics.title: Design goals vs business goals is a false split
topics.summary: Katie pushes back on separating business and design goals, emphasizing shared outcomes and the need for multidisciplinary checks and balances (emotion/trust vs metric hacks).

topics.title: Defining beauty: trust, emotion, and pride
topics.summary: Katie defines beauty as functional and partially objective, referencing Sagmeister/Walsh’s book and examples like Penn Station vs Grand Central; she ties beauty to trust, usability, pride, and attracting talent (plus a The Bear craft analogy).

topics.title: How Stripe builds a high-craft website
topics.summary: Katie explains Stripe’s website quality comes from tight design–engineering–product collaboration, including a structure where web engineers and designers report into the same org to iterate rapidly at a high bar.

topics.title: Operationalizing quality: vision, editing, courage, journeys
topics.summary: Katie shares principles learned from other leaders: quality is a group effort, requires vision/alignment, strong editing, and courage to say “not good enough,” plus a journey-based view of user experience.

topics.title: Stripe’s “walk the store” essential journeys program
topics.summary: To prevent quality regression, Stripe defined ~15 critical user journeys with accountable leaders who regularly “walk the store,” friction-log issues across the end-to-end journey (search → web → docs → dashboard), score them, and calibrate scores in reviews.

topics.title: Cadence, participants, and scoring mechanics
topics.summary: They cover practicalities: quarterly scoring with more frequent informal walkthroughs, doing reviews as a cross-functional trio, leadership calibration in PQR, friction logs with severity tags, and a color-based qualitative rubric to avoid false precision.

topics.title: Prioritizing quality fixes vs roadmap commitments
topics.summary: Katie explains Stripe relies less on rigid time-percentage formulas and more on hiring for judgment and pride, plus clear top-level advocacy and cross-functional planning to ensure quality work is continuously prioritized.
